projectDesc.p: "About the man who wounded Ridolfo (II da Varano di Camerino) with an arrow" is published by The Global Medieval Sourcebook (GMS), a free, open access, and open source compendium of medieval texts in their original languages and in English translation. GMS comprises computer-readable transcriptions or editions alongside new translations of texts dating from the ninth to the sixteenth century and originating in Europe, North Africa, the Middle East, and Asia. The GMS platform includes critical introductions as well as sources for further reading.

editorialDecl.p: Transcriptions and translations are encoded in XML conforming to TEI (P5) guidelines. The original-language text is contained within <lem> tags and translations within <rdg> tags.

interpretation.p: Texts are translated into modern American English with maximum fidelity to the original text, except where it would impair comprehension or good style. Archaisms are preserved where they do not conflict with the aesthetic of the original text. Scribal errors and creative translation choices are marked and discussed in the critical notes.

app.lem: Viri nonnulli Camerinenses extra urbem exercitii causa sagittando tempus terebant.
app.rdg: Some men from Camerino were passing the time outside of the city by practicing archery.

app.lem: Cum quispiam sagittam incautius emisisset, astantem procul Redolphum leviter vulneravit.
app.rdg: When one of them fired an arrow carelessly, it happened to lightly wound Ridolfo, who was standing nearby.

app.lem: Capto illo, cum variae de poena inferenda sententiae dicerentur, et, ut quisque acerrime sentiret, ita se maxime Principi gratificaturum putaret, unus censuit manum illi esse amputandum, ne amplius arcu uteretur.
app.rdg: The man was captured and different punishments were discussed, some thought it had to be very harsh so that it would be most pleasing to the prince, and one man even thought that the archer’s hand should be amputated so that he could never use a bow again.

app.lem: Redolphus liberum hominem dimitti iussit, dicens, illam futuram fuisse utilem sententiam, si id ante acceptum vulnus consilium dedisset.
app.rdg: But Ridolfo ordered the archer to be set free and said that this would have been a useful punishment, if the man had given the advice before he was wounded.
An answer full of wisdom and humanity.
